title: Irish One Direction star Niall Horan jokes about England fans after Rugby World Cup win

England’s Rugby World Cup stars were paid an unlikely tribute by Irish singer Niall Horan after their semi-final win over New Zealand on Saturday morning.

But the former One Direction star was far less complimentary about England supporters, labelling them “unbearable" after the 19-7 win over the All Blacks booked a spot in next weekend’s final.

Eddie Jones’ men handed New Zealand their first World Cup defeat in 12 years.

And Irishman Horan, who had seen his country destroyed by the back-to-back world champions in the quarter-finals, called the Red Rose “phenomenal” on social media.

(Image: Dave Hogan/Getty Images for BMI)

That only came however after Horan declared: "The thoughts of listening to so called English rugby fans now, makes me sick."

When asked about the performance from Jones' side, Horan added: "They are phenomenal. One of the best performances I've seen in a long time but...... the fans will be unbearable".

England dominated the All Blacks throughout in Yokohama, booking a first final spot since 2007.

Jones was remaining focused after the final whistle however and insisted he doesn’t care if the Red Rose are favourites when they meet either South Africa or Wales.

"We don't bet. We don't look at the bookies, we aren't concerned. Our expectation is to get better every day.

"We have another week in the competition, the prospect to work hard and see where we can take our game and get better.

(Image: REUTERS)

"We had great tactical discipline. You try and play at their game, you come off second best. We stuck to our game really well.

"I thought the discipline of our players was outstanding in attack and defence.”

Jones added: "They played really well, Steve Borthwick and Neal Hatley do a fantastic job with them, well drilled, tactically aware.”

England's hero of their 2003 World Cup success, Jonny Wilkinson, said the modern-day players were "superheroes".

"You look at the back-row guys, Curry and Underhill, their impact, it's immense," he said.

"It's easy to look at New Zealand and call them superheroes, but you have to do the same thing for our boys and give them credit.
description: England booked their World Cup Final place, a week after the ex-One Direction star's Ireland had been defeated by the All Blacks
